nodes.name: Aaron Thompson
description: Aaron has a B.S. in Engineering with an Electrical specialty from the Colorado School of Mines.  He further focused his skillset in business management by earning a Masters of Business Administration (M.B.A.) From Mesa State College.

His responsibilities at WestWater include coordinating new projects with clients including budget and schedule estimates, assigning project managers, and scheduling work.  This includes management of WestWater’s GSA Schedule.  He provides project management, coordination and technical services for environmental analyses and permitting of mineral and land proposals. Aaron assists project managers in keeping all projects on budget and prepares invoices for completed work.

Aaron is also responsible for the GIS department at WestWater, which develops project specific graphics and maps, detailing environmental impact and mitigations and provides project managers with spatial and data analysis of project specific field data.  Finally, he manages, maintains and upgrades the company computer and network systems.

nodes.name: Amie M. Wilsey
description: Amie has a B.S. in Environmental Science and Technology and has been a project manager with WestWater Engineering since 2008 and was elected President in 2019.

She has been responsible for environmental research, documentation and regulatory permit guidance, reclamation planning and monitoring, wetland delineation and mitigation, migratory bird surveys, and threatened and endangered species surveys.

She has been the project manager for several large linear pipeline projects, recreational trail projects, state and federal highway projects, oil and gas well pad developments and associated infrastructure. Strengths include project management, client and regulatory agency coordination, and baseline environmental resource surveys.

nodes.name: Dean Goebel
description: Dean Goebel has over 30 years of experience working as a geologist/hydrogeologist in the Western and Northern Plains regions of North America.

Mr. Goebel has managed and worked on a variety of environmental and engineering projects as a research hydrogeologist and private environmental consultant with over 20 peer-reviewed publications and symposium presentations, both nationally and internationally.

His specialty areas include unsaturated and saturated zone interactions involving contaminant hydrogeology and the movement of water through porous media, with an emphasis on soil interactions and nitrogen impacts on water quality.  Mr. Goebel’s experience with soils, plants, and hydrology has furthered his knowledge in wetland science, riparian zone management, and groundwater restoration.

As an expert in water, Mr. Goebel has been involved in numerous projects including aquifer assessment, groundwater and geochemical modeling, stream restoration, mineland reclamation, watershed management, HMS and HEC-RAS modeling, onsite wastewater treatment system design, and other wastewater applications/permitting.

nodes.name: Stephen T. LaBonde, P.E.
description: Steve is one of the founders of WestWater Engineering.  Steve is a Professional Engineer and has a Bachelor’s Degree in Civil Engineering from Colorado State University.  Steve has managed and been the project engineer or project manager on a majority of capital improvement projects undertaken by WestWater Engineering for the past 37 years.

Related experience includes water and sewer system evaluation, design of wastewater treatment systems, and construction oversight.  Steve has been directly in charge of capital improvements and served as District Engineer in an “on-call” capacity for the Orchard Mesa and Central Grand Valley Sanitation Districts located in the Grand Junction/Mesa County Persigo Wastewater 201 service area for over 20 years.

He has also acted in the capacity as Town Engineer for the communities of Crawford, Dinosaur, and Paonia. Steve was also a board member on the Water Resources and Power Development Authority for ten years from 2004 to 2014.  The Authority is in charge of the State Revolving Fund (SRF) program that funds numerous water and sewer capital improvements throughout the State of Colorado.

This experience has provided Steve with a unique knowledge of the funding sources and programs to assist communities in securing affordable financing for their projects. His expertise is not specific to only the SRF program administered by the Authority, but also other sister funding agencies within the State that often partners with the Authority by funding projects for the community.

nodes.name: Leah Weckworth
description: Leah has a B.S. in Environmental Science and Technology and has been a project manager with WestWater Engineering since 2008.

She has been responsible for environmental research, comprehensive noxious weed and vegetation management projects, documentation and regulatory permit guidance, reclamation planning and monitoring, and threatened and endangered species surveys.

She has been the project manager for several large linear pipeline projects from project permitting through reclamation monitoring and long-term vegetation management, as well as several oil and gas well pad developments and associated infrastructure.
Strengths include project management, client and regulatory agency coordination, reclamation and comprehensive vegetation management, and baseline environmental resource surveys.

nodes.name: Jeremy Gilliam
description: Jeremy Gilliam is a Professional Engineer at WestWater Engineering.  Jeremy holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Mechanical Engineering from Colorado Mesa University that he attained while working his way through school and supporting his family.

Jeremy began his career with WestWater Engineering 15 years ago as a CAD technician utilizing his knowledge of AutoCAD Civil 3D design software.  During his first ten years at WestWater Engineering as the lead CAD technician, he continued to expand his experience with design software while taking every opportunity to learn all the facets of the engineering discipline.

Over the past five years, Jeremy has transitioned to the lead design engineer for numerous projects.  Projects Jeremy has completed as lead design engineer include wastewater treatment plant improvements, sewer line replacements, lift station upgrade/replacement designs, river restoration projects, and water treatment and distribution system designs.

Jeremy does enjoy solving intricate water problems; however, he also thoroughly enjoys the challenges of construction oversight.  Jeremy believes in the engineering process and understands the value of providing the most feasible and economical solution for each project.
